   Assessment and Plan
 COAGULOPATHY
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure:  Required urgent intubation on
   transfer secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).
    Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the alveolar pattern
   seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is vasculitis - Wegener's
   granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity.  No
   clear infiltrate is seen, although pneumonia is possible given
   prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   worsening leukocytosis. Given bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose
   steroids (on prednisone 40+mg PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely
   increased O2 requirement, concern for PCP as well. No hemodynamic
   compromise to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been
   bedbound for prolonged period.
   - vent set at A/C 480x14 (rate reduced secondary to
   metabolic/respiratory alkalosis), FiO2 50% (slowly downtitrating as
   tolerated), PEEP 8
   - continue 40mg IV Q8 hours
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - continue cytoxan, consent given by daughter
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage this AM showed red blood.  Platelets
   98 this AM, therefore mucosal bleed unlikely (although may have uremic
   platelets). Coagulopathic, as below.
   - Serial hct Q6 hours
   - Type and cross 2 units pRBCs
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 or concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated.
   - Steroid therapy, as above
   - Will discuss use of Cytoxan with renal
   - Renal recs
   - Avoiding renotoxic agents
   - Plasmaphresis on hold at this point per blood bank
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be nutritional
   given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to sample being
   drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still elevated to
   >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**];
   unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of OMR. Concern for
   DIC given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia as
   well.
   - Suspect if inhibitor is playing role that high dose steroids, Cytoxan
   should be of benefit
   - Add on fibrinogen, haptoglobin, FDP, fractionate bilirubin
   - Monitor DIC labs [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis with left-shift given high-dose
   steroids, although continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection -
   without productive cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient
   did present with uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of
   ciprofloxacin.
   - Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - BAL at time of bronchoscopy
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to start if she decompensates
   .
   #. Metabolic/respiratory alkalosis:  Likely secondary to tachypnea
   prior to intubation in addition to Bicitra (started for low bicarbonate
   secondary to renal dysfunction). Rate increased, Bicitra discontinued.
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  Blood pressure improved with intubation. Written for
   labetalol at this time.
   .
   #. Anemia:  At baseline since admission. Initially attributed to renal
   dysfunction. Several likely contributors currently, including DAH. Also
   with recent GI bleed. Also concern for DIC/hemolysis currently given
   hyperbilirubinemia, decreasing platelet count.
   - Checking DIC labs, as above
   - Smear to assess for schistocytes
   - Maintain hematocrit >25, giving one tranfusion pRBCs now
   .
   FEN:  Careful repletion of lytes given renal failure, NPO at this time
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots (avoiding all heparin products), PPI IV,
   bowel regimen PRN
   Access:  Pheresis catheter, PIV - may need CVL if any hemodynamic
   instability, A-line (for frequent ABGs)
   Code status:  FULL CODE, confirmed with patient's HCP
   Communication:  [**Name (NI) 747**] (daughter, HCP), ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7905**]
   Disposition:  ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Will start tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  SSI given high dose steroids
   Lines:
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2138-9-12**] 10:25 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2138-9-12**] 02:59 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Pneumoboots
 avoiding heparin products at this time
   Stress ulcer:  PPI IV
   VAP:  Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  [**Doctor First Name 747**] (daughter, HCP), ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7905**]
   Code status:  FULL CODE
   Disposition:  ICU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, glomerulonephritis, and suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure and was intubated due to fatigue and airway protection. Bronchoscopy revealed diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), which is suspected to be related to vasculitis. She received one session of dialysis and was given 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) due to elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT).

The patient's condition is complicated by coagulopathy, respiratory failure, and glomerulonephritis. She has a high risk of bleeding due to DAH, and her platelet count is decreasing. She also has anemia, hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, which may indicate hemolysis or DIC.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient's risk of bleeding is high due to DAH, coagulopathy, and decreased platelet count.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to ongoing DAH and potential complications such as pneumonia or pulmonary embolism.
3. Glomerulonephritis: The patient's glomerulonephritis may progress, leading to worsening renal function and potential complications such as hypertension, proteinuria, and nephrotic syndrome.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to increased bleeding risk and potential complications such as DIC.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, hemolysis, or DIC.
6. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia may indicate hemolysis or DIC, which may worsen her condition.
7. Infection: The patient's risk of infection is high due to her compromised immune system and prolonged hospital stay.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's risk of pneumonia is high due to her respiratory failure and potential aspiration.
9. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's risk of pulmonary embolism is high due to her prolonged bedrest and immobility.
10. Cardiac complications: The patient's risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, and myocardial infarction is high due to her age, hypertension, and potential cardiac comorbidities.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk closely and consider transfusing platelets and plasma if necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
3. Consider starting antibiotics if the patient develops a fever or shows signs of infection.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her dialysis regimen as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and consider transfusing fresh frozen plasma or platelets if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusing packed red blood cells if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's hyperbilirubinemia and consider treating it with phototherapy or exchange transfusion if necessary.
8. Consider starting anticoagulation therapy if the patient's coagulopathy persists or worsens.
9. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust her medications as needed to prevent cardiac complications.
10. Consider referring the patient to a nephrologist or pulmonologist for further management of her glomerulonephritis and respiratory failure.

 COAGULOPATHY
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure:  Required urgent intubation on
   transfer secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given
   hemoptysis).  Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the
   alveolar pattern seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is
   vasculitis - Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis
   given pANCA positivity.  No clear infiltrate is seen, although
   pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and worsening leukocytosis.
   Given bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone
   40+mg PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement,
   concern for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   - vent set at A/C 480x14 (rate reduced secondary to
   metabolic/respiratory alkalosis), FiO2 50% (slowly downtitrating as
   tolerated), PEEP 8
   - continue 40mg IV Q8 hours
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - continue cytoxan, consent given by daughter
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage this AM showed red blood.  Platelets
   98 this AM, but may have uremic platelets.  Pt is coagulopathic, as
   below.
   - Serial hct Q6 hours
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 or concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated.
   - Steroid therapy, as above
   - continue cytoxan
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   - Plasmaphresis on hold at this point per blood bank
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be nutritional
   given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to sample being
   drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still elevated to
   >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**];
   unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of OMR. Concern for
   DIC given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia as
   well.
   - Suspect if inhibitor is playing role that high dose steroids, Cytoxan
   should be of benefit
   - Add on fibrinogen, haptoglobin, FDP, fractionate bilirubin
   - Monitor DIC labs [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis with left-shift given high-dose
   steroids, although continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection -
   without productive cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient
   did present with uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of
   ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to start if she decompensates
   .
   #. Metabolic/respiratory alkalosis:  Likely secondary to tachypnea
   prior to intubation in addition to Bicitra (started for low bicarbonate
   secondary to renal dysfunction). Rate increased, Bicitra discontinued.
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  Blood pressure high in the 180s this AM
   .
   #. Anemia:  transfused 2 units pRBCs yesterday.  Several likely
   contributors, gastritis, DAH.  Also concern for DIC/hemolysis currently
   given hyperbilirubinemia, decreasing platelet count.
   - DIC labs [**Hospital1 **]
   - Smear to assess for schistocytes
   - Maintain hematocrit >25
   .
   FEN:  Careful repletion of lytes given renal failure, NPO at this time
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots (avoiding all heparin products), PPI IV,
   bowel regimen PRN
   Access:  Pheresis catheter, PIV - may need CVL if any hemodynamic
   instability, A-line (for frequent ABGs)
   Code status:  FULL CODE, confirmed with patient's HCP
   Communication:  [**Name (NI) 747**] (daughter, HCP), ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7905**]
   Disposition:  ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Will start tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  SSI given high dose steroids
   Lines:
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2138-9-12**] 10:25 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2138-9-12**] 02:59 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Pneumoboots
 avoiding heparin products at this time

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old female admitted with glomerulonephritis and now presents with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, acute hemoptysis, and coagulopathy. She was intubated due to fatigue and airway protection. Bronchoscopy revealed diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, and the patient has been receiving high-dose steroids and immunosuppressive therapy. She has a history of gastritis, and OG lavage showed red blood. The patient has a coagulopathy with elevated INR and PTT, and is suspected to have DIC. She has a high-dose steroid-induced leukocytosis and metabolic/respiratory alkalosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxic respiratory failure is a significant concern, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory arrest.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy with elevated INR and PTT increases the risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial bleeding, and bleeding into joints.
3. DIC: The patient's suspected DIC could lead to further bleeding complications, organ failure, and death.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's high-dose steroid-induced leukocytosis could lead to leukostasis, which could cause respiratory failure, cerebral edema, and other complications.
5. Metabolic/respiratory alkalosis: The patient's metabolic/respiratory alkalosis could lead to seizures, arrhythmias, and other complications if not managed properly.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastritis and OG lavage showing red blood increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be exacerbated by her coagulopathy.
7. Renal failure: The patient's pre-existing glomerulonephritis and potential for further kidney damage from immunosuppressive therapy increases the risk of renal failure.
8. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and immunosuppressive therapy increase the risk of infection, which could be complicated by her respiratory failure and coagulopathy.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor her respiratory status, coagulopathy, and metabolic status, and to adjust her therapy accordingly. Regular laboratory testing, including complete blood counts, coagulation studies, and electrolyte levels, should be performed to monitor her response to therapy. Additionally, the patient's family should be educated on her condition and the potential complications, and a plan for code status and end-of-life care should be discussed.

 COAGULOPATHY
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure:  Required urgent intubation on
   transfer secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given
   hemoptysis).  Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the
   alveolar pattern seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is
   vasculitis - Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis
   given pANCA positivity.  No clear infiltrate is seen, although
   pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and worsening leukocytosis.
   Given bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone
   40+mg PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement,
   concern for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   - vent set to be changed to ARDS protocol, P/F ratio 208 this AM
   - recheck ABG after vent changes
   - continue 40mg IV Q8 hours
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - continue cytoxan, consent given by daughter
   - monitor hematocrit TID
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage this AM showed red blood.  Platelets
   98 this AM, but may have uremic platelets.  Pt is coagulopathic, as
   below.
   - check hematocrit TID
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated.
   - Steroid therapy, as above
   - continue cytoxan
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   - Plasmaphresis on hold at this point per blood bank
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be nutritional
   given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to sample being
   drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still elevated to
   >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**];
   unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of OMR. Concern for
   DIC given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia as
   well.
   - Suspect if inhibitor is playing role that high dose steroids, Cytoxan
   should be of benefit
   - Add on fibrinogen, haptoglobin, FDP, fractionate bilirubin
   - DIC labs normal today, check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if
   abnormal
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis with left-shift given high-dose
   steroids, although continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection -
   without productive cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient
   did present with uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of
   ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to start if she decompensates
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  Blood pressure high in the 180s this AM in setting of
   bradycardia.  Given transient PTT of 150, consider intracranial bleed.
   Decrease of propofol resulted some improval of heart rate.
   - head CT today
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   .
   #. Anemia:  transfused 2 units pRBCs yesterday.  Several likely
   contributors, gastritis, DAH.  Also concern for DIC/hemolysis currently
   given hyperbilirubinemia, decreasing platelet count.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Nutrition
 nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   FEN:  Careful repletion of lytes given renal failure, plan to start
   tube feed
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots (avoiding all heparin products), PPI IV,
   bowel regimen PRN

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, glomerulonephritis, and suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure and hemoptysis, requiring urgent intubation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Acute hypoxic respiratory failure, with bilateral diffuse infiltrates on CXR, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) on bronchoscopy.
* Cardiovascular: Hypertension, with a blood pressure of 172/61 mmHg, and a heart rate of 60 bpm.
* Hematological: Anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.3 g/dL, and a platelet count of 98 K/uL.
* Coagulation: Coagulopathy, with an INR of 13.0 and a PTT of 35.0, and a suspected inhibitor of Factor VIII.
* Renal: Glomerulonephritis, with a suspected diagnosis of hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
* Gastrointestinal: Lower GI bleed, with a suspected diagnosis of diverticular vs. ischemic colitis.
* Infections: Leukocytosis, with a WBC count of 16.2 K/uL, and a suspected infection.

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Propofol for sedation
* Furosemide for fluid management
* Cyclophosphamide for immunosuppression
* Prednisone for immunosuppression
* PPI IV for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Cytoxan for immunosuppression
* Inhaled pentamidine for PCP prophylaxis

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 98 K/uL
* INR: 13.0
* PTT: 35.0
* WBC count: 16.2 K/uL
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* LDH: 252 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.2 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* CXR: Bilateral diffuse infiltrates
* Bronchoscopy: DAH
* BAL: 2+ PMN, no organisms
* Viral culture: Pending
* BCx, UCx: Pending

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Vent set to be changed to ARDS protocol
* Recheck ABG after vent changes
* Continue 40mg IV Q8 hours of prednisone
* Monitor hematocrit TID
* F/U Rheumatology recs
* F/U Renal recs
* Consider plasmapheresis if DIC is suspected
* Hold off on antibiotics unless patient decompensates
* Wean propofol as tolerated
* Start tube feeds
* Continue PPI IV for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Continue inhaled pentamidine for PCP prophylaxis

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Coagulopathy
* Anemia
* Leukocytosis
* Lower GI bleed
* Infection
* DIC
* Hypertension
* Hydralazine-induced vasculitis

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent these complications and improve her outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a diagnosis of pulmonary-renal syndrome, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, and renal failure. The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they require mechanical ventilation. The risk of further respiratory deterioration is high, and the patient may require increased ventilatory support.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which may lead to bleeding complications. The patient's platelet count is low, and they require close monitoring to prevent bleeding.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and they require dialysis. The risk of further renal deterioration is high, and the patient may require further interventions to maintain renal function.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and they require close monitoring to prevent further bleeding.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may worsen their overall condition. The patient requires close monitoring and transfusion support as needed.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and they require close monitoring to prevent bleeding.
7. Bradycardia: The patient has bradycardia, which may be related to cyclophosphamide or other medications. The patient requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further cardiac complications.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is critical, and they require close monitoring to prevent further complications.
9. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly given their immunosuppressed state. The patient requires close monitoring for signs of infection and prompt treatment if infection occurs.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The patient's condition is complex, and the medical team should work together to provide comprehensive care and address any potential complications that arise.

though ? cyclophosphamide related given temporal

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a complex medical condition, including:

1. Pulmonary-renal syndrome with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) and hypoxic respiratory failure.
2. Positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA) and possible hydralazine-induced vasculitis.
3. Acute renal failure (ARF) with p-ANCA-positive vasculitis, possibly microscopic polyangiitis.
4. Leukocytosis, possibly due to steroids.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) with hemoccult-positive stool, possible gastritis.
6. Coagulopathy, with elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and positive inhibitor screen, possibly due to inactivation of clotting factors or evolving disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
7. Thrombocytopenia, possibly due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
8. Bradycardia, possibly due to exaggerated vagal tone or cyclophosphamide-related effects.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7C (98F)
* Heart rate: 67 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 163/76 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 16.2 K/L
* Platelet count: 134 K/L
* Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 145 mg/dL

* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* LDH: 252 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 4.2 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: diffuse bilateral alveolar infiltrates
* Bronchoscopy: diffuse blood from airways

The patient's medical treatment includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with assist-control mode
* Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with FiO2 50%
* Propofol infusion
* Furosemide infusion
* Cyclophosphamide
* Solumedrol
* Plasmapheresis (held)
* Heparin (held)
* Antibiotics (held)

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Acute renal failure
* Leukocytosis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Coagulopathy
* Thrombocytopenia
* Bradycardia

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: start total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Glycemic control: monitor glucose levels and adjust insulin as needed
* Lines: continue dialysis catheter, multi-lumen catheter, and peripheral IV lines
* Prophylaxis: continue stress ulcer prophylaxis with proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis with boots
* Communication: continue regular communication with the patient's family and healthcare team
* Code status: full code
* Disposition: ICU

   small effusion
   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis,
   improved from yesterday.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Pt changed to AC ARDS NET
   protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F ratio of 208. Pt on
   spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today. Tried on PSV 8/5 this AM
   and did well. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).
   Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the alveolar pattern
   seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is vasculitis - Wegener's
   granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity.
   Pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis. Given
   bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone 40+mg
   PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement, concern
   for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   -Check ABG on PSV
 if ok, will wean PSV to [**5-20**]. Perhaps will do SBT
   today if pt tolerates PSV well with possible extubation today or
   tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage without output now. Decreasing
   amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis yesterday for fluid overload
   per Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   -Possible plasmapheresis
 will f/u with blood bank
   - f/u renal recs and t/b re: next plan for dialysis.
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission but 1.1 today with PTT
   33.1. Unlikely to be nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT
   suspected secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent
   pheresis line, although still elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of
   note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being
   inhibited by review of OMR. DIC labs nl. Heparin products stopped and
   platelets now rising, concerning for HITT.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   -f/u HITT antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis given high-dose steroids,
   stable. No clear evidence of infection - without productive cough,
   abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient did present with
   uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to treat for VAP or HAP if she
   decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol, will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions yesterday. Several
   likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow
   -Will t/b with family re: goals of care and pt
s improvement
   -Will defer palliative care c/s at this time.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2138-9-14**] 02:38 AM 10 mL/hour; TFs held this
   AM for possible extubation
   Glycemic Control:  ISS given high dose steroids

   20 Gauge - [**2138-9-12**] 02:59 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2138-9-12**] 09:39 PM L IJ

 avoiding heparin products at this time

   VAP:  bundle

   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis,
   improved from yesterday.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Pt changed to AC ARDS NET
   protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F ratio of 208. Pt on
   spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today. Tried on PSV 8/5 this AM
   and did well. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).
   Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the alveolar pattern
   seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is vasculitis - Wegener's
   granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA positivity.
   Pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis. Given
   bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone 40+mg
   PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement, concern
   for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   -Check ABG on PSV
 if ok, will wean PSV to [**5-20**]. Perhaps will do SBT
   today if pt tolerates PSV well with possible extubation today or
   tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage without output now. Decreasing
   amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis yesterday for fluid overload
   per Renal.

   -Possible plasmapheresis
 will f/u with blood bank

   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents

   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission but 1.1 today with PTT
   33.1. Unlikely to be nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT
   suspected secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent

   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is

   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol, will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions yesterday. Several
   likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a complex medical history, including glomerulonephritis, hypertension, and vasculitis. She was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure and was found to have bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ARDS NET protocol and is being ventilated with a tidal volume of 350 mL, FiO2 of 40%, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.46, PCO2 of 41 mmHg, and PO2 of 96 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and she is on propofol to control her heart rate. Her cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm, and her peripheral pulses are 2+.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure is not monitored, but her blood pressure and heart rate are being closely monitored.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 1,042 mL of fluid since admission, with a total output of 164 mL.
* Laboratory results: The patient's WBC count is 16.2 x 10^9/L, Hct is 24.3%, and platelet count is 134 x 10^9/L. Her creatinine is 3.0 mg/dL, and her potassium is 4.4 mEq/L.
* Imaging: The patient's CXR shows bilateral patchy opacities, which are improving. Her CT scan shows no evidence of pulmonary embolism.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia: Given the patient's prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis, pneumonia is a possibility.
* Pulmonary embolism: Although the patient's CT scan shows no evidence of pulmonary embolism, it is still a possibility given her prolonged immobility.
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's ARDS NET protocol and ventilator settings suggest that she is at risk for ARDS.
* Vasculitis: The patient's pANCA positivity and hydralazine-induced vasculitis make vasculitis a possibility.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastritis and lower GI bleed make gastrointestinal bleeding a possibility.
* Hypertension: The patient's labile blood pressure and history of hypertension make hypertension a possibility.
* Anemia: The patient's Hct of 24.3% and history of bleeding make anemia a possibility.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated INR and PTT suggest a coagulopathy, which could be secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line or Factor inhibition.

The patient's goals of care are to be extubated and go home. Her daughter is aware of her mother's elderly status and understands that her condition is critical. The patient is currently on full code status, and palliative care consultation is deferred at this time.

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of hemoptysis
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure:  Required urgent intubation on
   transfer secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given
   hemoptysis).  Bronchoscopy showed DAH, which correlates with the
   alveolar pattern seen on CXR.  Included in the differential is
   vasculitis - Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis
   given pANCA positivity.  No clear infiltrate is seen, although
   pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and worsening leukocytosis.
   Given bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone
   40+mg PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement,
   concern for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   - vent set to be changed to ARDS protocol, P/F ratio 208 this AM
   - recheck ABG after vent changes
   - continue 40mg IV Q8 hours
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - continue cytoxan, consent given by daughter
   - monitor hematocrit TID
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage this AM showed red blood.  Platelets
   98 this AM, but may have uremic platelets.  Pt is coagulopathic, as
   below.
   - check hematocrit TID
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated.
   - Steroid therapy, as above
   - continue cytoxan
   - f/u renal recs
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   - Plasmaphresis on hold at this point per blood bank
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission. Unlikely to be nutritional
   given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT suspected secondary to sample being
   drawn from heparin-dependent pheresis line, although still elevated to
   >150 on peripheral stick. Of note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**];
   unclear which Factor is being inhibited by review of OMR. Concern for
   DIC given anemia, decreasing platelet count, hyperbilirubinemia as
   well.
   - Suspect if inhibitor is playing role that high dose steroids, Cytoxan
   should be of benefit
   - Add on fibrinogen, haptoglobin, FDP, fractionate bilirubin
   - DIC labs normal today, check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if
   abnormal
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis with left-shift given high-dose
   steroids, although continues to rise. No clear evidence of infection -
   without productive cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient
   did present with uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of
   ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to start if she decompensates
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  Blood pressure high in the 180s this AM in setting of
   bradycardia.  Given transient PTT of 150, consider intracranial bleed.
   Decrease of propofol resulted some improval of heart rate.
   - head CT today
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   .
   #. Anemia:  transfused 2 units pRBCs yesterday.  Several likely
   contributors, gastritis, DAH.  Also concern for DIC/hemolysis currently
   given hyperbilirubinemia, decreasing platelet count.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Nutrition
 nutrition consult for tube feeding

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female admitted with glomerulonephritis, now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the context of hemoptysis. The patient required urgent intubation due to fatigue and airway protection.

The patient has a complex medical history, including hypertension, gastritis, and suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis. She has undergone dialysis and has received cyclophosphamide therapy.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation with a P/F ratio of 208
* Hemoptysis with DAH seen on bronchoscopy
* Coagulopathy with an elevated INR and PTT
* Leukocytosis with a left shift
* Anemia with a hematocrit of 24.3%
* Hyperbilirubinemia
* Decreasing platelet count
* Hypertension with a blood pressure of 180/76 mmHg
* Bradycardia
* Abdominal distension with hypoactive bowel sounds

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Pneumonia
* Pulmonary embolism
* Pulmonary edema
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypotension
* Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy
* Infection (e.g., urinary tract infection, pneumonia)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Ischemic colitis
* Diverticulitis

The patient is at risk for developing sepsis, multi-organ dysfunction syndrome, and death due to her complex medical condition and multiple organ dysfunction.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a P/F ratio of 208
* High-dose steroids for vasculitis and respiratory failure
* Cyclophosphamide therapy for vasculitis
* Dialysis for renal failure
* Antibiotics for suspected infection
* Anticoagulation therapy for coagulopathy
* Fibrinogen and haptoglobin levels to monitor coagulation status
* DIC labs to monitor for disseminated intravascular coagulation
* Nutrition consult for tube feeding
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI IV
* VAP bundle for prevention of ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis with pneumoboots

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90+ year-old female with a complex medical history, including renal-pulmonary syndrome, acute respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for management of her condition.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 98%. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.46, PaCO2 of 41 mmHg, and PaO2 of 240 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 132/48 mmHg, and her heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL and a urine output of 149 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Hematological: The patient has leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has gastrointestinal bleeding, with a positive stool test for hemoccult.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which is likely due to pulmonary-renal syndrome and p-ANCA vasculitis. The patient's lung infiltrates are improving with fluid removal and treatment of underlying vasculitis.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute kidney injury, which is likely due to p-ANCA vasculitis and possibly hydralazine-induced vasculitis. The patient's creatinine level is 3.0 mg/dL, and her urine output is 149 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has coagulopathy, with an elevated PTT and positive inhibitor screen. The patient's thrombocytopenia is improving, and she is off all heparin products.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which is likely due to steroids. The patient's white blood cell count is 16.2 x 10^9/L.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has gastrointestinal bleeding, which is likely due to gastritis or swallowed hemoptysis. The patient's stool test is positive for hemoccult.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is likely due to p-ANCA vasculitis and possibly hydralazine-induced vasculitis. The patient's platelet count is 134 x 10^9/L.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 98%.
* Dialysis: The patient is receiving dialysis, with a creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL and a urine output of 149 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Immunosuppression: The patient is receiving immunosuppressive therapy, including steroids and cyclophosphamide.
* Blood products: The patient is receiving blood products, including platelets and fresh frozen plasma.
* Gastrointestinal management: The patient is receiving gastrointestinal management, including proton pump inhibitors and nasogastric suction.

The patient's potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if the patient's lung infiltrates do not improve or if the patient develops pneumonia.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if the patient's creatinine level continues to rise or if the patient develops sepsis.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen if the patient's PTT continues to be elevated or if the patient develops disseminated intravascular coagulation.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may worsen if the patient's white blood cell count continues to rise or if the patient develops sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen if the patient's bleeding is not controlled or if the patient develops gastrointestinal perforation.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if the patient's platelet count continues to decline or if the patient develops disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of her complex medical conditions. The patient's treatment plan should be individualized to address her specific needs and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90+ year-old female with a complex medical history, including renal-pulmonary syndrome, acute respiratory failure, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). She has been admitted to the ICU for management of her condition.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a tidal volume (TV) of 350 mL, and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. Her respiratory rate (RR) is 22 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 98% on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure (BP) is 132/48 mmHg, and her heart rate (HR) is 73 beats per minute. Her cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) with a creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL. She is on hemodialysis (HD) therapy.
* Hematological: The patient has leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and anemia. Her platelet count is improving.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) with heme-positive stool. She is on proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy.
* Coagulation: The patient has a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and an elevated D-dimer level, suggesting a possible coagulopathy.
* Infections: The patient has a positive BAL culture for PCP, and is being treated with pentamidine.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further interventions to improve her oxygenation and ventilation.
* Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she is at risk for further kidney damage.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's PTT is prolonged, and she may be at risk for bleeding.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has GIB, and may require further management to prevent further bleeding.
* Infection: The patient has a positive BAL culture for PCP, and may require further antibiotic therapy.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and she may be at risk for bleeding.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she may require further management to improve her anemia.
* Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is slow, and may require further management to improve her cardiac rhythm.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue PPV therapy to improve her oxygenation and ventilation.
* Continue HD therapy to manage her ARF.
* Monitor her respiratory status closely and adjust her therapy as needed.
* Manage her coagulopathy with anticoagulant therapy.
* Manage her GIB with PPI therapy and close monitoring.
* Continue antibiotic therapy for her PCP infection.
* Monitor her platelet count closely and adjust her therapy as needed.
* Monitor her hemoglobin level closely and adjust her therapy as needed.
* Manage her bradycardia with atropine therapy.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to improve her outcomes.

   [**Age over 90 **] year-old female with hypertension, admitted with glomerulonephritis,
   now with acute hypoxic respiratory failure in context of diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, thought to be hydralazine p-ANCA induced
   vasculitis.
   #. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Most likely due to DAH secondary
   to hydralazine induced p anca vasculitis.  Differential includes
   Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic polyangiitis given pANCA
   positivity. Pneumonia (including PCP) is possible given prolonged
   hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and
   leukocytosis. Initially required urgent intubation on transfer
   secondary to fatigue and airway protection (given hemoptysis).  Pt
   changed to AC ARDS NET protocol due to b/l infiltrates on CXR and P/F
   ratio of 208. Pt on spectrum of [**Doctor Last Name 2**] to ARDS, much improved today.
   Patient currently on CPAP/PSV 8/5 doing well. No hemodynamic compromise
   to suggest pulmonary embolism, although patient has been bedbound for
   prolonged period.
   -Check ABG on PSV
 if ok, will wean PSV to [**5-20**]. Perhaps will do SBT
   today if pt tolerates PSV well with possible extubation  tomorrow
   pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  likely due to DAH seen on bronchoscopy or dialyzing off
   clotting factors. Given history of gastritis, GI bleed also possible.
   Decreasing amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct
   stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   - transfuse plasma
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis today for fluid overload per
   Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   - plasmapheresis this PM
 will f/u with blood bank
   - f/u renal recs and t/b re: next plan for dialysis.
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission but 1.0 today with PTT
   33.1. Unlikely to be nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT
   suspected secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent
   pheresis line, although still elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of
   note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being
   inhibited by review of OMR. DIC labs nl. Heparin products stopped and
   platelets now rising, concerning for HITT.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   -f/u HIT antibody
   -d/c antiplatelet antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis given high-dose steroids,
   stable. No clear evidence of infection - without productive cough,
   abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient did present with
   uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to treat for VAP or HAP if she
   decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol (SBP>160), will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions yesterday. Several
   likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   - [**Hospital1 **] Hct
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow

s improvement

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of hypertension, glomerulonephritis, and acute hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) and suspected hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV 8/5 with an ABG of 7.50/36/82/29, which suggests improvement from earlier. The plan is to wean the PSV to 5-20 and possibly do a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) today, with possible extubation tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and the plan is to wean propofol as tolerated. If the blood pressure remains elevated off propofol (SBP > 160), the patient may restart home labetalol.
* Renal: The patient has glomerulonephritis and is on dialysis today for fluid overload. The plan is to continue steroid therapy and cytoxan, and to perform plasmapheresis this afternoon.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR and PTT, but the plan is to check coags daily and add on DIC labs only if abnormal.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has stable leukocytosis, and the plan is to follow Sputum, blood, and urine cultures, as well as BAL results.
* Lower GI bleed: The patient had a single episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**] and is suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
* Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, and the plan is to transfuse for hematocrit > 25.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia: Given the patient's prolonged hospital course, immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis, pneumonia (including PCP) is a possible diagnosis.
* Pulmonary embolism: Although the patient has been bedbound for a prolonged period, there is no hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary embolism.
* Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HITT): The patient has an inhibitor screen positive and is being treated with heparin products, which may increase the risk of HITT.
* Infection: The patient has a high-dose steroid regimen and is at risk for infection, particularly given the prolonged hospital course.
* Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastritis and lower GI bleed, and the plan is to monitor her hematocrit and transfuse if necessary.
* Nephrotoxic agents: The patient is at risk for nephrotoxic agents, and the plan is to avoid them.

The patient's goals for care are to be extubated and go home, and the plan is to attempt extubation today or tomorrow. The patient's daughter is aware of her mother's condition and understands that she is elderly.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, glomerulonephritis, and acute hypoxic respiratory failure due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) secondary to hydralazine-induced p-ANCA vasculitis.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on CPAP/PSV 8/5 with a FiO2 of 0.4, and her ABG results show a pH of 7.50, PCO2 of 36, PO2 of 82, and HCO3 of 29. The plan is to wean the PSV to 5-20 and consider a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) today, with possible extubation tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and she is receiving propofol infusions to control her heart rate. The plan is to wean the propofol as tolerated.
* Renal: The patient requires dialysis for fluid overload, and she will receive plasmapheresis this afternoon. The plan is to follow up with the renal team and adjust the dialysis plan as needed.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR and PTT, which may be related to her p-ANCA vasculitis. The plan is to monitor her coagulation status daily and add on DIC labs if necessary.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, but there is no clear evidence of infection. The plan is to monitor her for signs of infection and hold off on antibiotics unless necessary.
* Lower GI bleed: The patient had a recent episode of bleeding, which may be related to diverticular disease or ischemic colitis. The plan is to monitor her for further bleeding episodes.
* Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is stable, and she is not requiring transfusions at this time. The plan is to transfuse if her hematocrit falls below 25.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and she may require further interventions to manage her respiratory failure.
* Bleeding complications: The patient's bleeding disorder may lead to further bleeding episodes, including GI bleeding, which can be life-threatening.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may lead to bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage.
* Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state may make her more susceptible to infection, including pneumonia and sepsis.
* Renal failure: The patient's kidney function is impaired, and she may require further dialysis or renal replacement therapy.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypertension and vasculitis may lead to cardiovascular complications, including myocardial infarction and stroke.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current status, it is essential to closely monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent potential medical complications.

   Pneumonia is possible given prolonged hospital course,
   immunosuppression with steroid therapy, and leukocytosis. Given
   bilateral patchy opacities on high-dose steroids (on prednisone 40+mg
   PO daily since [**2138-8-30**]) and acutely increased O2 requirement, concern
   for PCP as well. No hemodynamic compromise to suggest pulmonary
   embolism, although patient has been bedbound for prolonged period.
   -Check ABG on PSV
 if ok, will wean PSV to [**5-20**]. Perhaps will do SBT
   today if pt tolerates PSV well with possible extubation today or
   tomorrow pending her clinical status and oxygenation.
   - continue salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours and cytoxan per Rheum recs
   - Given high-dose steroids, PPI IV, PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (inhaled
   pentamidine given [**2138-9-6**]), close glucose monitoring
   - monitor hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - F/U Rheumatology recs
   - F/U Renal recs
   .
   #. Hemoptysis:  DAH seen on bronchoscopy.  Given history of gastritis,
   GI bleed also possible.  OG lavage without output now. Decreasing
   amounts of old blood and no new blood from ETT lavages. Hct stable.
   - check hematocrit [**Hospital1 **]
   - PPI IV given known gastritis, high-dose steroids
   - Goal hct>25 for concern for active bleeding
   .
   #. Glomerulonephritis:  Suspected hydralazine-induced pANCA vasculitis.
   Patient with renal biopsy on [**2138-9-1**] which showed 'marked chronic
   vascular disease' and suprisingly no evidence of vasculitis, although
   pANCA level markedly elevated. Dialysis yesterday for fluid overload
   per Renal.
   - Steroid therapy and cytoxan, as above
   -Possible plasmapheresis
 will f/u with blood bank
   - f/u renal recs and t/b re: next plan for dialysis.
   - Avoiding nephrotoxic agents
   .
   #. Coagulopathy:  INR elevated on admission but 1.0 today with PTT
   33.1. Unlikely to be nutritional given albumin 4.1. Elevated PTT
   suspected secondary to sample being drawn from heparin-dependent
   pheresis line, although still elevated to >150 on peripheral stick. Of
   note, inhibitor screen positive [**2138-8-26**]; unclear which Factor is being
   inhibited by review of OMR. DIC labs nl. Heparin products stopped and
   platelets now rising, concerning for HITT.
   - Check coags daily, add on DIC labs only if abnormal
   -f/u HITT antibody
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Expected leukocytosis given high-dose steroids,
   stable. No clear evidence of infection - without productive cough,
   abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria. Patient did present with
   uncomplicated UTI and was treated 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
   - f/u Sputum, blood, and urine cultures
   - f/u BAL results
   - Hold off on antibiotics, low threshold to treat for VAP or HAP if she
   decompensates as ARDS may mask infiltrate on CXR
   .
   #. Lower GI bleed:  First and only episode of bleeding on [**2138-9-9**].
   Suspected to be diverticular vs. ischemic colitis given vasculitis.
   .
   #. Hypertension:  BP labile.  Intracranial bleed unlikely as pt is
   responsive and head CT deferred. Decrease of propofol resulted some
   improvement of heart rate with increase as pt was previously
   bradycardic.
   - wean propofol as tolerated
   -if BP elevated off propofol, will restart home labetalol
   .
   #. Anemia: Hct stable requiring no transfusions yesterday. Several
   likely contributors, gastritis, DAH.  DIC labs unremarkable.
   - transfuse for hematocrit >25
   .
   # Goals for care
 Daughter would like mother to be healthy enough to
   be extubated and go home. She understand mother is elderly. Yesterday,
   situation was more critical but pt is much improved on exam today.
   -Attempt to extubate today or tomorrow
   -Will t/b with family re: goals of care and pt
s improvement
   -Will defer palliative care c/s at this time.

 avoiding heparin products at this time

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female admitted with glomerulonephritis, acute hypoxic respiratory failure, and hemoptysis. The patient has undergone several interventions, including intubation, bronchoscopy, and plasma pheresis. The patient's condition has improved significantly, with the ABG showing a pH of 7.50, PCO2 of 36, and PO2 of 82.

The patient's respiratory support is being weaned, and the plan is to attempt extubation today or tomorrow. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 16.7, hematocrit of 28.0, and platelet count of 114. The patient's coagulation profile is concerning, with an elevated INR and PTT, and a positive inhibitor screen. The patient's coagulation status is being monitored daily, and the plan is to add DIC labs if abnormal.

The patient's medications include salumedrol 40mg IV Q8 hours, cytoxan, and ppi IV. The patient's nutrition is being managed with NovaSource Renal (Full), and glycemic control is being monitored due to high-dose steroids.

The patient's goals of care are to be extubated and go home, and the plan is to discuss this with the family and the patient. The patient's daughter is aware of the patient's elderly status and understands that the patient may not be able to achieve full recovery.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and the plan is to wean the respiratory support. However, the patient's underlying lung disease and the possibility of ARDS may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Bleeding: The patient has a history of hemoptysis and has undergone plasma pheresis. The patient's coagulation profile is concerning, and the patient may be at risk for bleeding.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of UTI and has been treated with antibiotics. The patient's immunosuppressive therapy may increase the risk of infection, and the patient's white blood cell count is elevated.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and the patient may be at risk for intracranial bleed.
5. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is stable, but the patient may require transfusions if the hematocrit falls below 25.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation profile is concerning, and the patient may be at risk for bleeding or thrombosis.
7. Lower GI bleed: The patient has a history of diverticular disease and may be at risk for lower GI bleed.
8. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to the presence of an endotracheal tube and the patient's underlying lung disease.
9. HAP: The patient is at risk for HAP due to the patient's underlying lung disease and the possibility of aspiration.

Overall, the patient's condition is improving, but the patient is still at risk for several medical complications. Close monitoring and management of the patient's respiratory, bleeding, and coagulation status are essential to prevent complications and improve the patient's outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old female admitted with glomerulonephritis, acute hypoxic respiratory failure, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). She was initially intubated due to fatigue and airway protection, and bronchoscopy showed DAH. She has been on high-dose steroids, cytoxan, and plasma pheresis. Her current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.1C (98.7F)
* Heart rate: 61 bpm
* Blood pressure: 158/51 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: She has been on CPAP/PSV and is expected to be extubated today or tomorrow.
2. DAH: She has been bleeding from her airway and has had old blood suctioned from her endotracheal tube.
3. Coagulopathy: Her INR is elevated, and she has a positive inhibitor screen, which may be related to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HITT).
4. Leukocytosis: Her white blood cell count is elevated, but she does not have a clear infection.
5. Anemia: Her hemoglobin level is low, and she has been transfused with plasma.
6. Hypertension: Her blood pressure is labile, and she has been treated with propofol and labetalol.
7. Glomerulonephritis: She has been treated with steroids and cytoxan, and her kidney function is improving.
8. Lower GI bleed: She has had a single episode of bleeding, which may be related to diverticular disease or ischemic colitis.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pneumonia: Given her prolonged hospital course and immunosuppression, she may be at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Pulmonary embolism: Although she does not have hemodynamic compromise, she is at risk for developing a pulmonary embolism due to her prolonged bedrest.
3. Acute kidney injury: She has been treated with dialysis, and her kidney function may continue to deteriorate.
4. HITT: Given her positive inhibitor screen, she may be at risk for developing HITT.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: She has had a single episode of bleeding, and she may be at risk for further bleeding due to her underlying medical conditions.

The patient's goals of care include being extubated and going home, and her daughter is aware of her mother's age and the risks associated with her medical condition.

   [**Age over 90 **] yo F w/ acute hypoxemic resp failure in setting of renal pulm

    ISSUES INCLUDE:
          Respiratory failure, acute, hypoxemic

   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 DAH in context of pulmonary-renal
   syndrome/p-anca vasculitis (Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic
   polyangiitis vs hydral-induced vasculitis).  Further confounded by
   uremic platelets and thrombocytopenia.  Less likely pulmonary
   infection, but pna is difficult to assess in setting of diffuse b/l
   infiltrates.  S/p bronch with BAL  to r/o infection.
   --- F/u cx data.
   ---Continue PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (pentamidine)
   ---Hold on antibiotics at this time, unless obvious signs of
   infection/clinical decline.
   ---Continue steroids and cytoxan.  Rheum and renal input appreciated.
   Transfusion service input appreciated
will continue with
   plasmaphoresis.
   ---ABGs and imaging improving with fluid removal (HD) and treatment of
   underlying vasculitis, now on PS wean
   ---Confortable w/ continue with PS.  Now requiring increased Fio2 from
   prior.  Will reevaluate after phoresis/HD for SBT possible extubation
   though with recurrent bleeding from ET as major barrier to extugbation
   at this time.  Continue to reasses..
   # ACUTE RENAL FAILURE/p-anca + vasculitis-- Probable microscopic
   polyangiitis.  Possibly [**2-17**] hydralazine-induced vs wegeners.
   --Continue HD.
   --Continue solumedrol and cyclophosphamide, and  plasmaphoresis.
   # Leukocytosis
in setting of steroids.  No obvious infectious etiology.
   --Follow pending micro, empiric broad antibx in setting of clinical
   decline as above.
   # GIB with heme pos stool. Possible gastritis. NG lavage neg.  ? [**2-17**]
   swallowed hemoptysis.
   --Monitor for evidence for GI bleeding and continue ppi.  Maintain HCt
   > 25.
   # COAGULOPATHY
elevated PTT (lower on repeat check) with positive
   inhibitor screen.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent inactivation of clotting factor or
   evolving DIC given thrombocytopenia and elevated bili.
   --Immunosupression as above.
   --Without evidence of DIC
   # THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- declined by 50% since admission, now improving,
   --Remains off heparin products.
   --HIT antibody pending.  Need to clarify that this was sent.
   #HTN
consider resuming home antihtn regimen if remains of sedation
   (propofol) if elevated > 160.
   # GOALS OF CARE
continue to address goals of care and update family.
   Will talk with consulkting services further regarding prognosis.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in the setting of renal-pulmonary syndrome with ARF/GN and DAH. The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, pulmonary-renal syndrome, leukocytosis, gastrointestinal bleeding, coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, and hypertension.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further hypoxia and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Pulmonary-renal syndrome: The patient's underlying condition can progress, leading to further damage to the lungs and kidneys.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis can worsen, leading to increased risk of infection and sepsis.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding can worsen, leading to hemorrhagic shock and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can worsen, leading to further cardiac strain and potentially life-threatening complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes continued respiratory support, dialysis, and management of underlying vasculitis, as well as close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results. The patient's family has been informed of the patient's condition and goals of care have been discussed.

   Acute resp failure [**2-17**] DAH in context of pulmonary-renal syndrome
   [p-anca + vasculitis (Wegener's granulomatosis vs. microscopic
   polyangiitis vs hydral-induced vasculitis).  Further confounded by
   uremic platelets and thrombocytopenia.  Infection appears less likely,
   though pna is difficult to assess in setting of diffuse b/l infiltrates
   and with ongoing intubation and immunsupression she is at high risk for
   developing a VAP.  She is s/p bronch with BAL to r/o initial infection
   and we continue to follow imaging and clinical status closely. Although
   yesterday we were hopeful that we were moving toward extubation, at
   present barriers to extubation include the need for increased FIO2
   (large A-a gradient) and recurrent bleeding from ET sx.
   Agree with plan to continue PS ventilation, adjusting settings by abg
   (will tolerate paO2 > 60).  Will continue to reassess for
   SBT/extubation after HD and phoresis. We continue cytoxan, steroids and
   phoresis with rheum, renal, and transfusion service input appreciated.
   Will continue PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 3261**] (pentamidine).   She continues with HD
   for clearance and volume removal.
   She continues to have an impressive leukocytosis, in  the setting of
   steroids, with no obvious infectious etiology. We follow pending micro,
   and will initiate empiric broad antibx in setting of clinical decline
   as above.
   Pt had elevated PTT with + inhibitor screen, w/o evidence of DIC.
   Phoresis also impacting labs.  Immunsupression treatment should help,
   and we continue to monitor.
   Pt with profound thrombocytopenia with > 50% decline during course, now
   improving.  We continue to hold all heparin products.
   HIT antibody is pending (Need to clarify that this was actually sent.)
   H/o htn as baseline.  We are holding meds while sedated and undergoing
   HD.  Continue to assess for restarting with conservative BP parameters.
   Will continue to update family and address goals of care, working with
   renal/rheum services to provide information regarding prognosis.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TFs
